nodes.text: PCA-based dimensionality reduction can improve machine learning performance for hyperspectral optical imaging regression tasks (soil moisture estimation) while preserving predictive capability
Hyperspectral optical imaging produces high-dimensional, highly correlated spectral data that challenge machine learning due to the curse of dimensionality
The study dataset contains 679 samples with 125 hyperspectral bands (450-950 nm) and reference soil moisture measurements collected with a TRIME-PICO sensor from bare soil
Dimensionality reduction was performed using PCA after standardizing spectral features with StandardScaler; the number of components was chosen to retain >99% cumulative variance
Predictive performance was evaluated by training a Random Forest regressor (100 trees) on PCA-transformed data, using a 30% test split and fixed random state for reproducibility, and scoring with R2
Adjacent hyperspectral bands show strong inter-band correlations and redundancy, implying lower intrinsic dimensionality than nominal spectral resolution
Dataset acquisition details: Cubert UHD 285 snapshot camera, 50x50 pixel images across 125 contiguous bands (~4 nm resolution), five-day campaign in May 2017 near Waldbronn/Karlsruhe, Germany
Data preparation included importing into Python, splitting features X and target y, fixing numpy random seed 42, inspecting soil moisture distribution, and standardizing features
PCA results: PC1 explains 98.89% variance, PC2 explains 0.64% variance; cumulative variance after two PCs is 99.53%, and scree plot shows sharp eigenvalue drop after PC2

Retaining only the first two principal components enabled improved visualization and clearer separation of samples by soil moisture, while higher components contributed negligible discriminatory power
Random Forest trained on PCA-transformed features achieved coefficient of determination R2 = 0.947 (94.7% explained variance) for soil moisture prediction
The combined evidence indicates PCA reduced dimensionality from 125 to 2 components while preserving predictive accuracy and enabling computational efficiency

Conclusion: PCA is an effective baseline strategy to reduce redundancy, improve interpretability, and maintain strong predictive performance for hyperspectral regression tasks like soil moisture estimation
Limitation and future work: Results are demonstrated on one dataset and PCA only; further evaluation across diverse sensors, scenarios, and alternative feature extraction methods is recommended
